I've recently gotten an internship at the ETPathfinder in maastricht. So i've been reading up a lot about gravitational waves lately and there are a few things i want to point out.
In this video it was a bit indicated as if shot noise was the only type of quantum noise, but it isn't. There is also something we call radiation pressure noise. This is a noise source that comes from photons transfering their momentum into the test mass (mirror) and moving it. This noise can be reduced by lowering the power of the laser. This sadly is a problem with the shot noise. I need a high power laser to lower shot noise but a low power laser to decrease radiation pressure noise. Luckily a few years ago a solution was found to this. In systems we now use what is called a partially transmitting mirror. This mirror keeps reflecting the light send it and making it do round trips. This builds up the effective power of the laser while still having a low power laser. So using this trick quantum noise in its entirety can be reduced.
You also indicated that if a gravitational wave was detected the locations in america would detect them at the same time. This is untrue as it depends on where the gravitational wave came from. There could be a small delay.
There are also more different kinds of noise that have multiple tricks that can be used to decrease said noise. I won't go into any detail about them as they weren't mentioned in this video. But i will say that one of the more important noise sources was left out here, which is thermal noise. Thermal noise is at the moment one of the bigger fields in GW because of the coating used and its inhomogeneous dissipation properties.
Anyway. I doubt anyone will ever see this comment so i'm gonna stop here.
For the person that does see this, i hope you enjoyed this small addition to the video

Since we are actually in a space-time continuum, how do you know that time isn't also warped as the wave passes, playing havoc with the assumption that tiny successive lab-time differences represent actual stretches or shrinks of the arm? And how does this two-way measurement of the time lapse differ from the controversy of measuring the one-way speed of light? Isn't a better explanation of the credibility of results that the orthogonal arm shows characteristically different behaviour (unless the gravitational wavefront meets both at the same angle)? And wouldn't a useful corroboration be yet a third orthogonal arm-pair at an equatorial 1/4 distance (geodesically) around the globe, to tap the azimuthal (z) direction (and confirm the shared x or y direction)? Until that happens I'm still skeptical that the experiment(s) haven't been scuppered by uncertainty.

As I type this, this piece is already four years old so I'm a bit behind the curve. To make matters worse, what I'm about to write will cause some to accuse me of being a Luddite, or worse. But I forge ahead. The earth is, by most estimates, about four billion years old. Humans have been around for a tiny fraction of that; maybe a couple of million years. These events, these collisions of super massive black holes have, likewise, been occurring for BILLIONS (imagine Carl Sagan saying that) years. So, here's my question: What is the VALUE of knowing that an event that occurred more than a billion years ago caused this ripple space-time such that we would be able to detect it? How will that knowledge be used to improve the lives of not just astrophysicists, engineers, mathematicians, astronomers and their support staff and the contractors and construction crews hired to build these detection devices; but how will all of this improve the lives of those who PAID FOR IT? I am a curator of bits and pieces of curiosities; arcane facts and statistics which I have, on occasion, used to impress others. But I have also managed to annoy others who expressed their annoyance by calling me a 'know-it-all' and much MUCH worse. Yet, that capacity for knowing arcane facts has never once actually improved my life or the lives of others beyond the momentary personal satisfaction I experience or that others may experience. It doesn't put food on my table or shoes on my children's feet or a roof over our heads. All of which brings me to my real question: Is there not a BETTER way to spend the BILLIONS of dollars required to hear these machines make that cute little 'Beep' sound that would positively impact the lives of a far greater number of human beings?

Once again, you are a remarkable presenter and I greatly admire and enjoy your work, including this one. But would you not agree that the questions I pose above are deserving of an answer?

Sorry folks, but this is pure pseudo-scientific poppycock. Humans do not possess the ability to “measure” the diameter of anything that’s 1/10,000th the diameter of a proton, let alone do it across 16 square km, let alone do it across a continent in two different locations, each with their own inertial frame of reference. The incredulous tone in the hosts voice is real — and should be, because these “research” scientists are little more than glory hounds seeking fame & fortune at the expense of the gullible.

Here are some sources of error in such ridiculously precise measurements:

1) Tidal forces
2) Inner core, molten dynamics
3) tectonic plate movement
4) earthquake tremors
5) solar flares
6) magnetospheric snap back
7) global lightning storms (aggregate)
8) temperature
9) pressure
10) humidity
11) wind
12) local traffic (not just trains)
13) noise from jets at 35,000ft
14) noise from birds, dogs, bears, etc.
15) planetary orbits
16) galactic rotation
17) waves from galactic center
18) solar current sheet dynamics
19) electricity fluctuations (power grid)
20) electricity fluctuations (circuitry)
21) accuracy of electrical equipment
22) degradation in electrical equipment
23) mirror / polishing flaws
24) time required for electrons in the electrical measuring equipment to cross from one side of a microcircuit chip to the other
25) many others

These sources of error are at least trillions of times greater than needed to make such sensitive measurements. Care can be used to reduce some of the errors: for example, one can use a 4-point probe to compensate for differences in the length & resistance of cabling to & from electrical equipment, in order to improve accuracy by three or four orders of magnitude. That gets you from 1E-12 to (at best) 1E-15 accuracy (one femtoampere in any given electrical device). As reported, one needs 1E-21 accuracy - a million times greater accuracy than any electrical measurement ever confirmed.

One can make more precise measurements with photonics, but only over very small distances: not over 4 km distances needed for gravity wave detection. Fiber optic cables run over the 4 km distance here introduces more sources of systemic error. Repeaters are inserted to keep the signal integrity. Photons can be absorbed by fiber defects (impurities), so a single photon cannot be relied on to travel in the fiber strand over 4 km.

The space in the tube is minutely stretched by the gravitational waves. This however, also stretches the wavelength of the light so no difference is observed. But, says the scientist, if we propagate a new wave down the tube it will detect the change in length. This makes no sense. If you propagate a light wave into a piece of space that is stretched, the wavelength of the light (the distance between each peak of the wave) will be stretched because space - i.e. distances - in the tube have been elongated. This also implies that, relative to a tube in which the space has not been stretched, the light in the stretched tube will travel faster which I'm sure violates something.

Let us first define a wave. The electromagnetic wave is often described as saw tooth ideograph. This is not correct. It is a stream of photons orbiting an imaginary line of transit at a radius of half the wave diameter. The wave travels in this fashion because universal gravity is tugging on the stream in all directions. A wave carries  photons on it dependent on its frequency which is dependent on the amount of mass consumed to convert it into photons. A ten billion frequency wave has ten times the number of photos and thus ten time the mass of o one million frequency wave. The more photons on the wave the smaller is the diameter of the wave because it has more mass resisting universal gravity on that wave form. A wave is thus a circular motion dictated by gravity and its force Waves on our oceans and lakes have another source of gravitational attractiveness and that is the gravity of the Earth. Such wavers are pulled by universal gravity only to the extent of their resistance to it as a mass and are controlled by the rotary motion of the Earth and its gravity to the largest extent possible. These waves appear to be linear in scope because of these limitations. We see circular waves of fluids only when fluids fall toward the center of the Earth through a tubular structure.. The point being that in the universe unless limitations are imposed on a motion it will always be circular around an imaginary line of transit. Gravity does not appear to be adhering to that model. Its force is only controlled by its distance from its primary source. While this force diminishes with distance it is constant from one point to another and dependent only on the mass of the point of measurement. A wave connotes a lull or dip in this force at some theoretical limit of distance. This does not appear to be the case neither from an observed criteria or a theoretical criteria.

Professional LIGO-like observatory for poor man.

We take 3 identical F-P 1-mode lasers with big distance between mirrors.
We place this 2 lasers in place of external mirrors.

Observation of interference pattern we do with lens and camera. Better choice is place there all Wafer of CCD sensors.
Sensors we connect and register the data (for example 1/seconds).
Processing of recorded data's. Interference pattern resembles central waves on water. We estimate parameters (center, phase, wavelength) of this interference pattern with correlation.
Now we create the 1-dimensional signal phase(t).
With DSP we extracts periodic like components.

Components known we rejects.
From 2 or more apparatus we look for components which repeats. By correlation we compute time shift between them.
Time shift allows us compute direction of signal which caused perturbation of our observatory.

Interpretation of results.
Knowing phase(t) we compute t1(t)-t2(t). It is the difference of time passing light in 2 branches. We can this interpretate like difference of length. In gravitational field object change length in the direction of gravitation. So if we know direction of variable gravity we can compute variation of lengths of branches. In practice we have to compute direction of variable gravity. This can be obtained from second apparatus.

In fact we don't know what caused this anomaly. Anomaly is in many apparatus so rather the common cause exists. If this are modes of vibrations of apparatus then phase change. Apart gravity cause can be neutrinos, photons (Gamma rays).

This enormous precision is related to fact that results is mean of of millions measurements. So random errors are annulate. Precision is really enormous.

MY CONCEPTS OF SPACE AND TIME
My concept of space has two strands closely linked to each other: space as an imaginary envelope where all things of the Universe reside, and Space as a Reference System that can have its origin and any orientation at any point in the Universe. So my concept of space is an imaginary thing where all things in the universe fit together; my space is not physical.
So my concept of "Space" is always three-dimensional. There are no two-dimensional or one-dimensional spaces. There are two-dimensional surfaces, and one-dimensional lengths.
My concept of "Time" is that of a frame-work to contextualize “when” and “for how long” events with things happen at any point of the Universe. So, the concept of “Time” is registered along an imaginary time-line.
That said, I just need to say that all attempts to link gravity to an effect of any "Space/Time "Fabric" Deformation" are simply BS.

I wish they had gone into what's in the tunnels a bit more. The tunnels are only 4 kms long. But in each tunnel is a device called a Fabry-Perot cavity. This has two functions, one is to keep the light in the tunnel for nearly a millisecond so the gravity wave has more time to interact with the light. The light bounces back and forth between two mirrors I believe 400 times, making the effectively length of the tunnel 1600 kms.


The other thing it does is increase the power of the laser light. They didn't mention it in the video, but the laser is only 200 watts. But in the Fabry-Perot cavity each refection of the light wave is in phase with the other reflections so you get constructive interference. This increases the power of the laser light to nearly a megawatt.


That poses an interesting engineering problem. When light hits those mirrors it actually pushes them a little. And that will vary with the amount of energy in the beam. If they don't account for that, the light itself would push the mirrors enough so the light would no longer be in phase since the distance between the mirrors would change. Also the light beam wouldn't be in the same spot anymore since the mirror is slightly tilted. There are equations to calculate the amount of deflection which they obviously do and account for mechanically.


Just a few tidbits they didn't cover in the video.

The LIGO-Virgo Collaboration has never published a calibration curve of detector displacement versus known laser input in the attometre range. Without a relevant calibration curve it is not possible to draw any conclusions from a measured detector signal to the strength of an alleged gravitational wave. Nonetheless, in their discovery paper the LIGO-Virgo Collaboration falsely claimed to have calibrated by means of known laser input for corresponding detector displacement. They state in their discovery paper: "The detector output is calibrated in strain by measuring its response to test mass motion induced by photon pressure from a modulated calibration laser beam . ... the detector response to gravitational waves is tested by injecting simulated waveforms with the calibration laser." Not only have they never published the required calibration curve, professor Karsten Danzmann of the Vigo Team confessed to professor Wolfgang Engelhardt (retired, of the Max Planck Institute), that the required calibration curve does not exist [see 1,2,3,4].
For months Danzmann stalled. Only after he found himself potentially before a German court of law to provide the calibration data according to German law, did he confess that the necessary calibration curve does not exist. He subsequently removed the calibration paper [5] from his profile on ResearchGate.
Furthermore, GW170814 proves that their published strain curves are not measurements, but the result of simulations. They publish equal strain of 5x10^(-22) as measured on all three interferometers, but due to different orientation of Virgo with respect to the wave front, the strain in Pisa would have been much less than in the US.
Anybody can confirm Danzmann's confession as to the non-existent calibration curve by writing to him and requesting his confession anew: danzmann@aei.mpg.de

When you asked the question about gravitational wave changing the wavelength of the light, I believe the professor was a bit confused. He said the photons in the stretched part are useless and the system works because they keep pumping light into the stretched space. This is wrong. The wavelength of the light changes but it doesn't change the speed of the light. But the distance that light needs to cover changes, so it still takes more (or less) time for the photon to travel that distance.


It is like a car that is 2m long travelling on a 3000m long road. Let say the middle of the car is in the middle of the road and, that means the front of the car is at the 1501m mark, that means the car needs to travel 1499m to finish the road. At that point, an enormous gravitational wave hits and stretches everything by 10%. Car is now 2.2m and the road is 3030m. The car is still in the middle, that means the front of the car is now at the 1516.1m mark. That leaves exactly 1513.9m. Gravitational wave changed the distance from 1499m to 1513.9m and even though the length of the car changed the speed of the car didn't change. This means it will take the car longer to reach the end of the road.


Stretched light waves are still useful. In fact, any light pumped into the stretched space will also change wavelength.

Okkkk...First, the original 'detection' of gws (back in 2014) had to be withdrawn after it was found that a cloud of gas in deep space was responsible (or at least, compromised the data). Second, the later, second 'discovery' coincided with a heavy geomagnetic disturbance that day, and professional radio astronomers have noted that such could produce currents in the Ligo arms...distorting them. Moreover, the tolerances of the separate mirrors between the two Ligo observatories are hardly less - if at all -  than the spatial tolerances of the Ligo detection signals. In addition, the time differences of reception between the two Ligo obs makes the 'detection', again, highly problematic. Finally, the signal was one fifth of a second...meaning that two supposed coalescing black holes('supposed' as these were determined through computer modeling, not astronomic observations) came violently together in some incredible cosmic disturbance...and that this lasted but one fifth of a second.......What few are willing to discuss is that Einstein's General Relativity did not explain gravity; it merely imposed a mathematical structure to which a metaphysics was added in which 'space' was now some sort of 'fabric' ..and that 'time', rather than being merely a non-spatial measure of change, was, again made over into a metaphysical object..whose metaphysical nature was then obscured by melding it with 'space' (which, prior, was deemed to be merely the emptiness between things). There are lots of comments re the impossibility of getting a fringeshift if the pipeline & the lightwaves suffer the same stretching. My understanding of LIGOs theory is that the distance tween the end mirrors stretches-contracts because they are loosely hanging (ie in effect in free fall) whereas the pipeline itself resists stretching-contracting by virtue of its solidness -- & the solid laser likewise resists, in which case the emitted light wavelength does not change at any time -- hencely a fringeshift. I dont believe in gravity waves (that is now the accepted term) -- i am just explaining the silly LIGO theory.
The need for such hanging mirrors means that a vertical 4km leg is not possible (suggested by some).

There are lots of comments comparing LIGO to an MMX. An MMX doesnt work in vacuum, u get a null result, thusly LIGO (being in vacuo) doesnt have to worry about any kind of MMX fringeshift, ie due to aether, ie due to the aetherwind. And even if LIGO did happen to get an MMX fringeshift the fringeshift would be very slow & steady & would have a period of 2 cycles per day (ie it would be well off LIGOs radar).

I just realized. The 1887-1932 oldendays MMXs were what is called 2nd order. Demjanov made a 1st order MMX in 1970. LIGO is i think a 3rd order MMX, even tho it is in vacuo (if the pipelines had air then LIGO would be a 2nd order MMX). Anyhow a 3rd order MMX will see a small fringeshift, but as already mentioned this would be very slow & steady (& very weak) & would have a period of 2 cycles per day & would be well off LIGOs radar.

He's wrong in multiple different ways about the energy that's in the laser and what it would do if you stick your head into it. Most obviously, the power added to the beam is only a 200 W. The power of the beam bouncing back and forth may be a megawatt, but that's kind of a funny measure, because as soon as you stick something into the beam the it would absorb the amount of energy stored as bouncing light, then the power of the beam hitting the obstruction is only 200 W. Since the power is constant and light can go through the detector 60 000 times in a second, I believe this means that the instantaneously stored energy as light will be only 1 MW/60 000 or about 30 J. This will not vapourize anybody's head; nor will the 200 J over the next second. Boiling water requires 2 MJ/L.

A 200 W laser can plausibly set your hair on fire or you can lose your eyesight if the beam is small enough. But of course, the beam is HUGE on LIGO. Just consider the Heisenberg uncertainty principle; if the beam goes through a tiny apperture you have determined the position of the photons and can know very little about their momentum, so the beam spreads out (diffraction) and you get a spread in the frequency of light. The LIGO beam from the look of the optics is about 30 cm wide. It's a gaussian beam so a lot of that surface won't be very strongly illuminated.

If you close your eyes and stick your head in you will be hit by 30 J as fast as you can stick your head in and 200 W over time. If you move your head around continously those 200 W should only feel a few times hotter than sunshine on a summer noon. You'd probably be pretty alright.

Even a much more powerful continuous laser will have problems vapourizing any large mass instantaneously. A lot of smoke will be generated when it hits almost any target and that smoke will spread the laser in all directions reducing the power on target greatly. This is particularly a problem with any consideration of using lasers to shoot down ICBM re-entry vehicles, which not only smoke like nobody's business due to the heat shield, but continually rotate and move so fast that the beam diameter invariably will be huge.

LIGO is trying to measure something that doesn't exist (gravity waves) coming from the combining of two objects that don't exist (black holes). There are so many problems with this detection besides the obvious ones what Veritasium mentioned:
1) Black holes can never be seen to combine. They would only be observed getting trapped on each other's event horizons, according to the Standard Model of consensus cosmology.
2) Gravity waves should never be able to escape the event horizon of a black hole.
3) If gravity waves existed, and travel at the speed of light, Earth would always be attracted to where the Sun was 8.5 minutes ago (remember, gravity waves are supposed to travel at the speed of light). Earth would constantly be attracted to a phantom Sun, and would spiral out of the solar system with 2000 revolutions. The same it true for all objects in the universe orbiting other objects.
4) What the hell is space-time? This is another thing that doesn't exist. Just because you can write a mathematical equation doesn't mean it has any connection to reality. Try pointing in the direction of time. Time is not a dimension. You can't bend space-time. Have a cosmologist explain space-time to you without using circular reasoning.
5) LIGO, even though has a better vacuum than interstellar space, is still full of neutrinos.
What LIGO detected was very likely a disturbance in the electromagnetic field around earth, which would have affected both the detectors.

Soooo..... in the original Michelson Morley interferometer experiment (which shocked and baffled the scientific community) the 'null' result (which detected no motion with regard to earth's 'spin' or 'movement') was explained away by one scientists hypothesis that the apparatus must've shortened by the exact amount that would give the previously expected result. That formula (the Fitzgerald-Lorentz contraction), which hypothetically accounts for a shortening of the measuring apparatus that occurs due to 'earth's motion', was contrived as a possible explanation of why the result showed no detectable motion of earth. Since nobody at the time had a better explanation, it was adopted and is now commonly factored in to such experiments. I have a hard time believing that by using the same instrument which failed to detect earth's motion a over hundred years ago that it can now be used to detect gravitational waves billions of light years away. Why would they utilize the same device which failed to register the motion of the earth itself, on which it sets, to detect a much, much fainter motion billions of light years from earth? And if the results show no waves (movement) then we just correct for shortening of the device due to earth's motion?? So, the motion couldn't be detected... due to the motion itself? ..... Is that really where we are with science?

Below is an excerpt from my book, Infinity, Time, Death and Thought.


I’m proud to say that I had done the mechanical design of two of the telescopes used in the LIGO, which were the Pick-off and End Mass telescopes. I also provided the mechanical design for the return beam calibration fixture from the mirrors at the end of each of the two-and-a-half-mile long vacuum tubes that a laser beam is bounced off of some 400 times. That’s the equivalent of a 1,000-mile distance between the source and its detector, and there are two legs that interference fringes are compared against.It’s good to know the distinction between the terms “gravity waves” and “gravitational waves.” A body such as the earth causes what are referred to as gravity waves. It’s the earth’s gravity that causes physical perturbations in our environment. These are seen on the surface of water and atmospheric conditions that oscillate the air. In other words, these are visible waves caused by the gravitational attraction of our planet or any other celestial body. On the other hand, gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime.

The physicists at Caltech related to me that the purpose of LIGO was not merely to detect gravitational waves, but to determine whether they travel at some speed or whether gravity is an instantaneous phenomenon. They either propagate or exert an instant attraction through spacetime as they warp the fabric of space, slightly shrinking and expanding the space between objects. The distances are minuscule, but can be detected using LIGO. These detectable waves, or as I prefer to call them, contractions, are illustrated on the Internet with two large masses such as neutron stars or black holes as they begin to revolve around each other. This causes what would be equivalent to making waves in a still pool of water by rotating two basketballs round each other. These characteristics have been illustrated on the Internet as looking like waves that propagate outward in a spiral pattern. This may not be the case. The intent of LIGO was to provide evidence for the idea that gravitational waves might be instantaneous rather than having a speed such as the speed of light.

From websites I’ve viewed, these only show one of the two possibilities in their graphics; this is the one that illustrates that gravitational waves propagate outward at some speed rather than being instantaneous. A spiral pattern would be present if gravitational waves do in fact propagate at some speed, such as the speed of light. However, if gravitational waves do not propagate, and they radiate outward instantaneously, LIGO would not be able to detect the difference. As mentioned, waves propagating at some speed are only what the Internet illustrations show using a spiral pattern. What I have never seen on any of the web pages I’ve looked at concerning the discovery of gravitational waves by LIGO is what gravitational waves would look like if gravity were exerted instantaneously. Unfortunately, all the Internet illustrations show gravitational waves moving out from their origin in the illustrated spiral.

To discover whether gravitational waves propagate at the speed of light or if they are an instantaneous effect is actually not possible, but at least one possibility can be eliminated. To eliminate one of these possibilities, the optical telescopes on Earth need to look in the spot where the event took place at the same time as the gravitational waves are being detected by LIGO. If they witness some sort of visible light, like an explosion, then they will know that gravity propagates at the speed of light. In other words, the gravitational waves would arrive at the same time as a multitude of photons emitted from the collision. If the optical telescopes see nothing, then gravitational waves have moved into the possibility that gravity is instantaneous, but we would not be able to prove this for possibly millions of years. This is because the gravitational wave arrived here at the same time the event took place, while its light would not arrive until far into our future.

If gravitational waves were instantaneous, their shape would look very different from website illustrations. They would simply appear as a rotating ellipse, rotating along a horizontal or equatorial axis of the two revolving objects with its strength diminishing with distance.

To exemplify this further, picture that the gravitational field of any spherical object is also spherical. If two spheres come into proximity, their combined gravitational field produces an elliptical shape. Now if these two bodies are spinning around each other, they would produce a rotating elliptical gravitational field. LIGO has no clue as to whether it detects the force of a gravitational ellipse or the force of a gravitational spiral. It only detects an increasing and decreasing sinusoidal pulse-like compression and expansion of spacetime when the two objects spin faster as they get closer together.

I have some doubts about reliability of their results and their scientific methods for the measurements of gravitational waves. How do they correct for the following:
1. The expansion and contraction of the tube the laser travels in. I know the Eiffel tower expands and contracts by 5 inches each day due to heating and cooling of the metal.
2. Micro earth quakes that happen all of the time have compression waves that would move the mirrors out of position.
3. The thermal expansion and contraction of the surface of the mirror they reflect the laser off of.
4. Variations in the density of the air the laser travels through would cause the light to bend and change the path length.
5. Expansion and contraction of the bedrock the lasers are mounted on could cause issues with the distance changing.
6. At these minute distances they are trying to measure even the gravitational pull of the moon as the earth rotates could affect the distances.
How to rule out the possibility that instead of gravitational waves they measured the variability of the speed of light?

You forgot to account for the fact that gravity waves distort/stretch both space and time as a unit. Therefore, using a laser as a "measuring stick" to measure that distortion is invalid because the time component is likewise distorted. The only way to measure the distortion is to use an undistorted "measuring stick" that is external to the gravity wave that's doing the distortion you're trying to measure. The only way to measure a gravity wave distortion from inside the gravity wave itself, is to use a "measuring stick" that is not affected by space or time (laser is affected by both). I don't think you'll ever find one of those, until you find another dimension from which to measure.

It is physically IMPOSSIBLE that LIGO's interferometers can really detect a motion/disturbance in the order  of 1/10,000 the size of a proton (10^ -15 m.) as they claim. The shortest time interval ever measured (by Max Planck Institute in Nov. 2016) is 850 zeptoseconds. But in that time interval a light beam has already traveled 3 x 10^8 m/s x 850 x 10^ -21 s = 2.55 x 10^-10 m. = 2.55 BILLION TIMES the alleged size (10^ -19 m.) LIGO's technicians claim they can measure, as a disturbance ("gravitational wave") interfering between laser beams. Moreover, under the nanometer  order of magniture (angstroms, picometers, etc.) we find the VIBRATIONS/OSCILLATIONS of atoms making the solid (silica) crystal lattices of mirrors, so the distance between the source of laser beams and the mirrors splitting them is becoming no longer stable:  impossible to really detect a change of distance (or of time interval, or of pulses in a time interval) under 0.2 nanometers. Any change below that size is wiped out and overlapped/cloaked by the oscillations of atoms. So, the claim by LIGO-Caltech technicians is totally bogus(see here https://www.academia.edu/34940695/_Gravitational_Waves_a_Nobel_Prize_to_a_Non-Discovery_)

Okay, so the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle may not apply, but the coarseness of the technology is still way too gross to measure something a thousandth the width of a proton.  In fact, doesn't quantum mechanics state that the time it takes light to cross a FULL width of a proton is the shortest time there is -- that that time is the shortest tick of the universal clock.  This ridiculously-minuscule scale is also the scale at which random quantum fluctuations happen, so surely you wouldn't know if you're detecting gravitational waves or quantum fluctuations.

Calling it a "one megawatt" laser is somewhat disingenuous. Yes, the power circulating inside the cavity is large, but that's just recycled laser power bouncing back and forth between the mirrors. The actual laser source is 200W.

With 4km arms, 1MW * 4 km / c = 13J of energy in the cavity. That's not going to blow your head off. Laser tattoo removal runs 1-2J per pulse (same wavelength as LIGO). Depending on how focused it is, 13J will probably just give you a burn. You need to be more concerned about the 200W of continuous laser power available at the source, which is in the range of a laser cutter.

Our theory says that gravitational waves would be produced by two black holes colliding but we do not know what a black hole physically is so we cannot determine what else two black holes colliding might produce.

In effect we have to believe that our experimenters have successfully ruled out interference from not only the forms of energy that we know about but also an unknown number of possible energy states that we do not presently know about in order for the experiment to be said to have proved the existence of gravitational waves. To summarize it is impossible at present to model a black hole's actual physical nature so we cannot secure both sides of the experiment but only our side of it.

What the experiment proves the existence of something which we choose to call gravitational waves because we want to believe in them since it validates our own theories and hence our own cleverness. Space-based LIGOs might make things easier.  We could place them at Lagrange points, make the arms a lot longer, and power >1MW lasers with solar, continuously -- and the vacuum is free.  The arms may have to be tethered though as drift would probably be an issue with the distances involved, but 10km struts in the weightlessness of space would not be an issue.  Having a few hundred of these guys scattered around our solar system would undoubtedly give us pinpoint accuracy of the origin of the waves.. and perhaps the ability to survey even more subtle waves, like those from supernovas or gamma-ray burst events.  Who knows how sensitive this will become.  Maybe one day we'll have so much gravitational wave data rolling in, we'll end up excluding much of it to focus on particular patches of the sky; a virtual solar-system-spanning steerable telescope of sorts.  I look forward to the combination of all possible data, EM and gravitational, to tell a more succinct story, and especially look forward to the many insights we'll garner from the far side of event horizons.

What about the linear thermal expansion at a measurable scale with a caliper or on a quantum level? If this device can detect a change in distance down to 1.0E-18 meters, then I'm sure it has to do with the thermal expansion and contraction of the mechanical components on this big rig.

Think about it:
I chose 410 stainless steel for the metal since it has a low thermal expansion coefficient [a], aluminum is over twice that.

Linear Thermal Expansion -
dL = L_o × a × dT

Where......

dL = 1.0E-18 m
L_o = 4,000 m
a = 9.9E+6 m/(m-K)
dT = ?

So......

dT = 1.0E-18÷[4,000 m × 9.9E-6 m/(m-K)]
dT = 2.5E-17 K

That is only a temperature change of 0.000000000000000025 degrees Celsius needed to show this change between the two waves of these lasers!
Not possible to control the ambient temperature in the lab to be that steady.

"Enough energy to power 1000 homes"

I know that "homes" is always used so that it is something that we can associate with, but the problem is that a homes energy varies a lot during a day. So a home is probably sized as 3 kW by a utility as that gives some buffer room and peaks will be smoothed out by neighboring houses that aren't using as much energy. This always bothers me in using this as a comparative model.

However 1 thing that i have noticed is that microwave ovens always seem to be about 1.1 or 1.2kW, so we could instead say that the laser is like running 840 microwaves simultaneously. It would be more accurate and everyone could imagine 840 hot pockets about to be ready to eat.

Geophysics is famous for measuring things to absurdly high precision.  The Benioff Seismometer is 220 lbs. of steel hanging on thin metal strips with a coil of copper wire moving in a magnet field.  The resulting electricity is fed to a galvanometer, a small coil of wire with a tiny mirror on it, suspended in a magnetic field by a gold fiber.  The system is powered by earth movement ONLY, no electronics whatsoever.  It can detect movements SMALLER THAN A HYDROGEN ATOM!  This is a purely mechanical device first made in 1932.  Of course, given megawatt lasers and state of the art electronics we now have, it's little wonder that motions of less than the diameter of a proton can be detected.  So, GO SCIENCE!

Great video! It gets the engineer / amateur astronomer in me excited. Here is why, a quick throw away term you mentioned: Shot Noise! A very important concept. That is one of the noise sources of amplifying devices. Another one is thermal noise, which is the unavoidable noise every electronic component has that is proportional to its resistance, the frequency bandwidth of the circuit, and the absolute temperature of the component. These noise sources combine statistically and make the design of sensitive electronics a challenge.

I now have a question for you. If they use one megawatt lasers as a signal source, how is that power dissipated in the receiver, the detector. People have been using much less power than that to cut metal. How can a sensitive detector survive being illuminated with that much power? I get the principal of boosting the power to increase the signal to noise ratio, but yikes! How do they do that?

Scientists need to stop deifying Einstein.
Yes, this measurement could indicate gravitational waves, but it is not the ONLY plausible explanation given those measurements, which means that the conclusion is premature.
The earth is a single data point, so "localized" interference also includes anything in our solar system, not just potential gravitational waves from lightyears away.

I posit that the desire to jump to a conclusion is because of the hero-worship of Einstein.
Maybe when we have done more tests, we will indeed conclude that gravitational waves are the only plausible explanation, but we are not at that point yet.
